Although Morath is the focus, about twenty
KRMA staff members have worked on the series.
Its combination of painstaking details and essen¬
tial simplicity reflects the direction of James W.
Case,the station’s indefatigable program director.
A thirty-two-year-old veteran of commercial tele¬
vision, Case, who has directed such ETV network
series as “Redman’s America” and the soon-to-
be-released “Our Neighbor: The Moon,” insists
that rigid professional standards guide KRMA’s
programming. He impresses the educational
stamp of the station even on the fifteen-second
station-identification breaks between programs,
each of which is a production in miniature. The
station’s letters are superimposed over reproduc¬
tions of works of art, ranging from a Rembrandt
or Picasso painting to a Frank Lloyd Wright
building. Classical music accompanies the break.
KRMA’s sign-off at the end of the day may be a
Walt Whitman poem or a folk song played against
a series of paintings, woodcuts, prints, and photo¬
graphs.
